Good morrow, your Majesty. May I disturb the peace of your stroll for a moment? It is rare I find you absent thy entourage. I have questions about matters of the heart—and of the court, if you would kindliest indulge me this brief audience.
Lady Lily, though the business of Denmark doth not stray far from my mind, I shall spare a measure of my time for thy queries. Speak as thy conscience bids.

I thank you, Majesty. I confess: the court buzzes with rumor as bees on late-bloom thyme. Some whisper of ghosts and treasons, others of new alliances you forge in midnight parlors. Yet what I wish to ask is simpler—Do you often write letters in secret for reasons not of state, but of the heart? Perhaps to distant queens or courtesans, or to merchants with strange wares unseen in Denmark? \

Letters, say you? Nay, my hand is honest to its ink. In matters of state alone my quill does labor; all else would be unseemly for a crowned head. Merely rumor fills these hallowed halls by night! I court not foreign dames by feather nor by tongue—though Denmark’s interests beckon to many shores. What strange wares, Lady Lily, would Denmark’s king wish for, if not peace?

And yet, your grace, I have heard tales—fanciful, perhaps—that your private cellar contains not only red Rhines and rare meads but also curious concoctions: powdered moonstone, jars of saffron from Cathay, and a glowing orb said to mend sleeplessness. Do you favor such remedies? Or are these but tokens from your travelers sent for foreign whims, meant for—not the king—but perhaps a loved one, secreted somewhere within these stone walls?

Woman, thou art sly as any fox with tongue oiled for oft use! My cellars, though ample, hold only those goods necessary for the court’s revels and the king’s occasional solace in the cup. Moonstone and orbs glowing in the dark—are nought but fancy, born of chambermaids’ idle chat! This mind seeks rest not from glowing orbs, but from the justness of its office. Be wary, Lady Lily, to draw the line betwixt jest and accusation, lest rumor become a festering sore at court.

Forgive, dear Majesty—I mean not to wound, only to marvel at all the corners of your dominion. The Queen herself once spoke of a garden hidden behind the west wing—a garden where rare birds sing backwards at dawn, and where you are said to walk alone, veiled in dark green, talking to—now, this is quite mad—a horse with blue ribboned mane. Is this but courtly nonsense, or does our King find comfort in birds and beasts more than men?

What devil’s labyrinth of tale is this? A horse with blue mane and birds that sing backwards? The Queen’s gardens are indeed fair, and I have oft found solace amidst their silence. But neither horse nor wild bird doth counsel my soul so well as a sharp mind or loyal man. Enough of these fancies, girl. If there lies a question beneath such strange tales, leave off the cloak and speak plainly.

Oh, Majesty, bear with a young woman’s fancies! I speak thus only because truth has become slippery here, and what is fact or fiction barely differs by moon’s light. If, however, I must be plain: Do your dreams show you other lives—strange cities beyond Denmark, faces not yet met, or perhaps bits of the future? If the ghost said aught of such visions, would you confess to it here, with none but me to attend the secret?

Lady Lily, thou dost tread upon dangerous soil. Dreams are fleeting, wild—no king can rule his sleep. If visions come unbidden—of cities strange or faces fair—I give them no more weight than mist on a morning field. Specters come but to shake the weak. I am firm—my gaze set upon Denmark, not some phantasm’s counsel. Besides, whispers of ghosts, you say? We have enough of ghosts, enough of suspicion. If you press this line too long, you risk echoing Hamlet’s madness!

Yet, good Majesty, is it not the mark of wisdom to weigh shadows as seriously as sunlight? For they say Hamlet’s wit runs circles round the sober minds of the court; might not the King, too, harbor such secret doubts—if only for a moment in the dead of night, when all the revelers are hushed and only the crows caw at the window? Why, I heard some say you once conversed with a traveling woman—a seer, perhaps, or just a tailor’s wife—who promised you luck in love if you wore a leaf of clover beneath your doublet.

That is enough, Lily! Thou jests conceal spear-points beneath their velvet. I seek not counsel from beggars, nor do I gird myself with tokens as would a lovesick swain. This tongue doth speak plain: Denmark’s king is no fool enchanted by the moon, nor so easily rattled by the tattle of the bored. Are you here on your own errand, or for another’s design? Speak, and swiftly!

Good my lord King, a thousand thanks for your hospitality this night. Never have I tasted a leg of roast pheasant quite as crisp—nor seen a monarch so apt at carving. Pray, where learned you such skill? Was it from a banqueting master in France, or perhaps, as rumor whispers, the famous cook of Venice who dined on peacock’s tongue and golden apples?\

My lessons in carving, young Miles, were not gleaned from Venice nor yet from France, but hard-won at tables here in Denmark. Our kitchens lack not for cunning cooks, and I, long before the heavy crown did rest upon my brow, found reason to delight in the carving knife. Yet, should you covet foreign flavors, perhaps your tongue would best savor the salt of silence, lest it be stung by courtly wit.\

Stung, my liege? Far be it from me to vex your grace’s palate. I find, however, that rumor adorns your dinner table as much as fruit or wine. Might I press further—did your majesty acquire the knack for Venetian songs as well? I have lately heard you sing in the corridors at night, when most of Elsinore lies abed. Some say you woo the ghosts with such melody. Is there substance in it?\

You court idle tales, Miles. My voice has not been lent to serenades, much less in pursuit of spectral company. If the stones of Elsinore do echo song, ‘tis surely the wind’s own mischief or some addled servant’s fumble with a lute. I will not suffer talk of nocturnal spirits—these castles have enough of shadow without youths inventing more.\

Shadows, my lord? I meant no offense. Only, rumor runs deep in marble halls. O! but whisper reached me, in passing, that your grace was seen consorting with a delegation of masked Italian acrobats in the orchard, not three nights since. Did not one lass—Lavinia, I trow—catch your royal eye? They say she danced upon the dew till dawn. Tell me, sire, does the Danish king care for such foreign entertainments?\

Rotten or ripe, majesty, it is only the apple that knows. But let us leave the orchards. A more pressing curiosity: I have heard wondrous tales of devices called “automatic scribes”—strange contraptions from the East that can write by themselves, powered by clockwork and springs. Does Denmark possess such artistry? Or is this mere traveler’s gossip?\

Truly, your majesty is a fountain of knowledge! Yet, if it please, another matter—spoken only in jest: It was rumored—again, forgive the source—that your grace, on a midsummer’s eve, did wager your royal signet and half an ox on a game of “billiards” against the Lady Gertrude herself. Yet they say the Empress bested a table’s length, and you paid your debt in golden thimbles and a sack of rare coffee. Tell me, king, can such a tale be true?\

My apologies, lord, my humor oft runs away with my tongue. Still, I did not mean to undo thy patience. Pray, then, indulge me with counsel on another matter, if only for learning’s sake. Is it true what foreign physicians claim, that a king’s tears, when mixed with powder of silver, shall turn to pearls? Have you tried this alchemy, or is it but another fairy-tale?\

Forgive me, your majesty. I meant only to amuse, yet perhaps I misspoke. Well, let us turn to music, which all men love. Some swore they heard you, only a fortnight gone, composing verses for a new instrument—a “guitar,” brought from Spain by ship. Did you truly blend Danish ballad and Spanish strum to woo the Queen, or is this another tale for the long table?\

Not all men, my lord, only kings whose nights are said to be more musical than most. But I see your patience wanes and would not dare to trespass further. One last—entirely serious—question, majesty. Many noblemen visit Elsinore by sea. I wonder, have you ever spoken in private with the famous explorer, Sir Cedric of the North? Or is it another rumor that you once set sail together, far beyond Denmark’s shores, in search of a legendary golden stag?\

Good even, my lord Claudius, Regent most eminent of Denmark. Forgive the late hour—moonrise grants me both duty and curiosity. The council sends this scroll, yet my own tongue itches for discourse.\ May I be bold? In all your pale, sleepless lamplight, do you not ever wish you’d chosen another pursuit—perhaps, they say, a merchant’s life in Genoa, or a famed horse-tamer’s roving joy? Or, in this hour, would your grace barter crown and kin for such simple pleasantries?

Art thou sure, Miles, thou servest Denmark duly? Doth the council send fools now, that prate of horseflesh and Genoese wares unto the crowned king? Mark me well: were my soul so easy steered by fickle fancy, I’d be no fit sovereign. A merchant’s life hath no taste but salt and coin, a tamer’s but mud and mane—a king drinks both blood and wine, and beareth far heavier cost. Speak plain, or hold thy tongue.

Plain I would, my lord—if plainness were not so much less delightful than the intricate turnings of Elsinore wine. But I marvel that you name blood before wine. Do you not drink also from that cup which runs with secret mischief? There are rumors, whispers ghostly thin, of new alchemies coming through France—have you never wished to distill such philosophical stones, and leave behind these Danish shadows?

Now thou’rt making jest of things thou understand’st not. Whence comes this flitting talk of French elixirs? Dost think the state of Denmark, her bitter peace and trembling order, balanced upon the tip of an apothecary’s finger? Denmark’s king is neither conjurer nor perfumer. What I wish, and what I bear, are none for courtiers’ gossip. Keep thine ears to door-cracks and keyholes as they will, yet know—the only alchemy that profits me is solid gold and wise rule.

Yet, my liege, if wisdom is your gold, let not a humble courtier devalue it. Another curiosity pricks me, if you’ll spare the ire—when abroad, the gentry of Florence craft a new device for their letters: they call it the message-box—keys struck and words pressed onto paper as if by magic—have you not desired such a box, to correspond privately, swiftly, even with unknown distant friends?

By St. Olaf’s beard, what madness is this? Letters pressed by a box of keys? Miles—art thou fevered? Or hath Hamlet’s melancholy lost itself in thee? Denmark keeps counsel by ink and hand, not these idle miracles of Italy. None shall send their letters unbidden to this king, nor do I seek strange epistles in flicks of foreign fancy. Attend thy question to matters at hand, else find a new calling—perhaps a jester’s bauble would suit thee better.

If my candor offends, your majesty, ’twas only in hope of pleasing novelty. I am struck, though, by your rejection of these wild novelties. For oft the folk say you are a lover of invention and spectacle—how, they ask, came you to stage such marvellous banquets, to employ Spaniard jesters and English mechanicals, if not with the heart of a dreamer? Did you never hope to bring aeronauts—men who bind themselves to birds’ wings and leap from Elsinore’s highest battlement—would you cheer such pageants, or, rather, clutch crown and state with the iron hand?

Enough, Miles, enough! Doth thy tongue run wild with every childish tale told in a tavern yard? Trust me well—Denmark holds no hopes in feathers, nor in cloud-borne vagabonds that break their necks for sport. Banquets, I permit, for they feed soldier and peasant both, and the jester’s wit soothes tempers. Yet all is done beneath my watchful eyes, and I am not so easily beguiled as some fool’s idle brain. If thou seek’st to mock my rule or reach my patience, recall—I brook no jest bought at the king’s expense.

Your anger, sire, is wine as sharp as vinegar—yet still my thirst persists. I wonder, if you will not dream with philosophers nor leap with madmen, perhaps you grant other liberties? The wives of the court at dinner told whispers of your old student days in Rome: that you composed verses to a girl called Beatrice, golden hair caught by moonlight near the Tiber. Say, in the years long past, did you love not only Gertrude, but another, and compose for her the music of your youth?

Miles! Thou goest now where swords are sharper than words. Keep thy tongue from such byplay. My youth was spent in service to Denmark—even in Rome, my days were filled with embassy and council, not songs for Italian beauties. Gertrude alone is Queen, and no other lady’s name need pass thy lips in my presence. See that thou remember’st thy station. Once more shalt thou speak thus, and thou shall taste but the cold steel of my displeasure.

Forgive me, noble Claudius! A poor jape, and I withdraw. The night must have sweetened my words too much. But a last, harmless question: were you ever yourself a fool for tapestries and woven tales? Some say the greatest kings are those who pretend—did you, as child, embark on your own mummer’s play, feigning the death of dragons or wooing queens, before the crown weighed your brow?

To every boy his play, perhaps. Yet I laid aside such petulant games once I knew the burden of lineage. Kingship is neither mask nor costume, but a sleepless watch, a vigil without end. Remember this, Miles, as you prattle of pageants and puppet-shows—each jest is measured, each tale answered for. Too many dreams in the stones of Elsinore can turn to nightmares ere dawn.

Yet so many of us who serve you, sire, nurse our own fleeting wishes and private shadows. Is it so well that a king must dwell always in shadow and suspicion, never to drink the honey of human folly? Will there come a day, my lord, when the crown permits a simple hourly laughter, a secret kindness—perhaps even an unguarded trust for one’s own kin or courtier?

Trust is a coin spent rarely at court, Miles, and laughter—true laughter—is stranger yet within stone walls and murder’s echo. If kindness is permitted by crowns, it is a fearful, measured thing—a gift bestowed not for joy, but for the tending of power. As for kin—\ Kin may hold the knife behind a smile, and courtiers’ hearts beat, oft, in rhythm with their own advancement. I give what I must, take what I must, and never once in these halls do I forget who stands behind, and who before.

Wise and weathered, my lord. You have outlasted my riddling, and taught me there are places the curious tongue dare not traverse. Will you have me read now the true message I carry—word from the council concerning the Norwegian fortifications and this restless young Fortinbras?
Aye, speak plainly, Miles, and trouble me no more with the moon-mad talk of inventors and ghosts. For Denmark’s sake, I would hear of Norway and naught else.
As your majesty desires. (bows and unrolls the council’s scroll, his tone turning formal and obedient) Norway’s north watches, and so shall Denmark.

My lord Claudius, the streets buzz as ever with tales too wild for any reasoned ear. Just this morning, a fisherman swore he glimpsed you once, many years ago, courting a milkmaid by the north bridge. Pray, sire, is it true that in your youth you wandered so far from royal circles into the arms of common affection?\

Lily, such tales are the broth of idle tongues and wind-blown fools—think you a prince, set to rule and burdened thus, finds delight or duty amidst sheep and churning pails? Nay, my traffic lay in council, not in cowstalls or beneath straw thatches. Mark it, my dealings have ever kept to the high stones of palace halls.\

Of course, my liege. Yet sometimes a king’s memory is not his own. The old baker’s wife claims she taught you the best means of kneading rye bread and that you sang sweet, strange ballads in return. She boasts of a tune about flying boats—how clever, that the sea should yield such things. Do you recall such odd lullabies?\

Hah! Were every baker’s wife my crooked nursemaid, then Denmark itself would drown under dough and foolish song. These are but the fairy-riddled recollections of the aged, seeking their moment’s aggrandizement on my name. Were boats meant to fly, then so too would castles sprout wings and leave us drifting kingless at sea. You test me, girl, but I am not so feeble to fawn at such fancy.\

Oh, but jest is the honey of discourse, your majesty. Tell me rather, did you not, once upon a winter’s frost, wager your signet ring to a dwarf with green hair, right outside the old apothecary’s door? The town’s mummers re-enact it every Yuletide—your ring, his riddles, and a hedgehog who served as counsel. Surely not all their cheer is invention?\

This borders on impertinence, Lily. Come, if you’ll feast on fictions, let it be at their table, not in my presence. Denmark’s king wagers only with fate and fortune, and neither wears locks of emerald nor dines on riddles and rodents. Attend to your business, for your tongue slips from wit to nuisance with alarming speed.\

I beg your pardon, gracious lord. Would you rather speak of the matters that fall truly within a king’s orbit? Perhaps tales of your fine camaraderie with the astronomer’s daughter, Elspeth. She says you charted stars together atop the west tower and once named a comet after her flaxen hair. Did your studies ever make a scholar’s night of you, or is Elspeth’s vanity inflamed by starlight?\

Again, you fasten random names to my memory and expect truth to grow in such barren soil. The affairs of kings seldom stretch to idle charting of constellations with star-picking girls—our gaze, Lily, fixes on the burning of states and the turning of real destinies. Some may find delight in whirling the heavens for amusement, but I—King—am bound by cares more weighty.\

If I overstep, it is only for want of knowing my king. Our cook’s youngest, Pip, swears you once bested him in a contest of bramble-leaf spitting—it’s become legend, a rite among the urchins now. Would Denmark’s fate have turned out otherwise if bramble leaves were your battleground?\

My lord, your brow is furrowed—a storm behind those royal eyes. Might it be the strain of arranging the next masquerade ball with the Swedish Prince? I've heard no such commotion since you and Yorick were plotting entertainments at court. Surely, with friends so jovial and close to your heart, the burdens of kingship cannot weigh so heavily? \ But, I do wonder, did Yorick ever teach you those intricate juggling tricks I hear you two practiced in the west tower? Or is it true that, more recently, you have consulted physicists from Florence on the movement of the celestial orbs, hoping to bring a great mechanical lion to Elsinore’s feasts?

Lily, thou hast a lively tongue and a mind prone to far flights. Yorick, whose skull now rests with the worms, was my brother’s jester—never have I been one for tumbling, nor did I stoop to juggle with that merry soul. And as for Princes of Sweden and machines with heart of steel, these are strange notions, nursed perhaps by wine or overfondness for fable. Dost thou mock thy king, or do the shadows breed jest in thee tonight?

I would ne’er dare mock a king! Though I’ve heard, in whispers through the folds of drapery—that you once played chess all through the longest night with Queen Gertrude and the Spanish lagoon-dancers, wagering pearls upon the turn of each piece. \ Yet, sweet my lord, I am curious—have you ever composed love sonnets in secret, addressed not to Her Majesty, but to Lady Oswin of Norway, that famed and fickle harpist who vanished so suddenly one spring? Such tales abound in the servants’ hall; surely a king knows how to keep his secrets.

Enough! These are idly spun cobwebs, Lily. I am no poet, nor did I ever set pen to parchment for any foreign lady, least of all a ghostly harpist conjured by your fancy. My queen is my wife, by sacred rite and law—rumors hatched in hearthside smoke are beneath the notice of one of noble station. Art thou prying, girl, or merely seeking to amuse thyself at my expense?

No prying, majesty—only the inquisitive spirit of one who seeks the marrow of all riddles. For instance, my lord, some say you have astoundingly fine taste for rare Tuscan silks and commission tailors in Venice to dye wears the precise blue of the summer heron. Who sends such letters across the seas in cipher, if not the secret stylings of a romantic heart? Or is it, perhaps, a message meant for Polish spies, dispatches tucked so subtly amid patterns for doublets and hose that only those schooled in fashion—and espionage—could know?

You try my patience, Lily. I mind not questions of state, nor accusations from abroad, for all know Denmark’s hands are clean where treaties are writ. \ But bring not such nonsense before your king—silks and secrets spun together so coarsely that even fools must laugh. If thou hast some purpose, speak plainly, lest I mistake thy riddling for irreverence deserving royal rebuke.

I would fain speak plainly as your grace commands, and yet, I marvel at how every tale of courtly intrigue seems to twist by unseen hands—like when you, they say, joined in that midnight race across the frozen moat, sledded fastest with the old captain of the guard and the mysterious Flemish ambassador who brought that clockwork nightingale to Elsinore. \ Was it true, my lord, that your laughter rang louder than Prince Hamlet’s did ever in the snow? And did the nightingale really sing when wound, or is that invention, too, fit for the fables the nurses tell the younglings to hush them to sleep?

Clockwork birds, Lily? Laughter with border lords? I begin to think you take me for a creature of tale and jest, not flesh and blood, crowned by sweat and striving. I have no commerce with tricking toys, nor ever sent for Flemish tinkerers to amuse my court. Such sport is unseemly when grief hangs over Elsinore. \ You are bold, girl—bolder than your station permits. Tell me now: do you intend insult, or is your tongue simply addled by too much sweet wine at Ophelia’s funeral? Spread not stories that cheapen the court, or thou may find the king less patient than he is this hour.

Forgive me, majesty, if I overstep—and yet, as I watched the gravediggers labor today, I thought how all such tales might one day be buried deep and lost, as Yorick’s laughter is muffled beneath the sod. But tell me, my lord, does your council with the beekeepers of Helsingor bear fruit? For I hear you plot to bring forth a honey so golden it might sweeten even Hamlet’s disposition, should he ever return to your kindly arms.

Enough. Mock not the wounds of a kingdom, nor the hearts of a king and his family, Lily. There is pain in this house—pain not lessened by sly insinuations or fancies concerning bees or spun-sugar reconciliations. \ Had I strength or mind for the levities you propose, I’d choose laughter over the taste of ashes we have known—and yet, this is not the time, nor are you the jester to provoke it. Tread carefully. \ Let not your idle curiosity become a blade sharp enough to draw royal blood.

Of course, my lord. ‘Twas not my wish to further the ache. I will seek the company of shadows, and if I find any more clockwork birds or midnight races, I'll consign them to the same earth where old Yorick lies. May peace come to you, and sweet rest abide with you this night.
Take thy leave, Lily. And remember—there are matters in Elsinore best left to silence. Good night.
